user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of init_rand_data:
```c
static int
init_rand_data (void)
{
#if ! defined(_WIN32) || defined(__CYGWIN__)
  int fd;
  ssize_t len;
  size_t off;

  fd = open ("/dev/urandom", O_RDONLY);
  if (-1 == fd)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Failed to open '%s': %s\n",
             "/dev/urandom",
             strerror (errno));
    return 0;
  }
  for (off = 0; off < sizeof(rand_data); off += (size_t) len)
  {
    len = read (fd, rand_data, 8);
    if (0 > len)
    {
      fprintf (stderr, "Failed to read '%s': %s\n",
               "/dev/urandom",
               strerror (errno));
      (void) close (fd);
      return 0;
    }
  }
  (void) close (fd);
#else  /* Native W32 */
  HCRYPTPROV cc;
  BOOL b;

  b = CryptAcquireContext (&cc,
                           NULL,
                           NULL,
                           PROV_RSA_FULL,
                           CRYPT_VERIFYCONTEXT);
  if (FALSE == b)
  {
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to acquire crypto provider context: %lu\n",
             (unsigned long) GetLastError ());
    return 0;
  }
  b = CryptGenRandom (cc, sizeof(rand_data), (BYTE *) rand_data);
  if (FALSE == b)
  {
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to generate 8 random bytes: %lu\n",
             GetLastError ());
  }
  CryptReleaseContext (cc, 0);
  if (FALSE == b)
    return 0;
#endif /* Native W32 */

  return ! 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Fragments not listed do not need investigation for Rule 8.13: local scalar declarations (fd, len, off, cc, b) are non-pointer objects so the rule does not apply; calls that pass integer/handle values (open, close, close return handling, CryptReleaseContext, GetLastError cast to unsigned long) involve non-pointer types; the &cc argument to CryptAcquireContext is a pointer to an output handle that the API is expected to modify, so making it a pointer-to-const would be incorrect; the read()/CryptGenRandom() uses are expected to write into the buffer (so the buffer pointer must be non-const) — nevertheless the specific read and CryptGenRandom calls are included above because of potential mismatches/casts and to verify the declared type of rand_data; string-literal usages as arguments are literal arrays of char which are inherently immutable in the source and are appropriate to pass to functions expecting const char * (therefore other uses of literals need no further investigation beyond the fprintf lines already listed that also pass strerror()).
